title: Layer 1: On-chain Scalability in Ergo
summary: The document discusses the Layer 1 scalability features of the Ergo blockchain. It highlights the Extended UTXO (EUTXO) model, protocol optimizations, and recent developments such as Just-in-Time Costing and miner parameter adjustments that have improved transaction processing capacity and overall throughput. The document also mentions future scalability enhancements, including the introduction of microblocks and the Ergo Block Extension Section, which enable faster block generation, improved transaction throughput, and support for service chains and sidechain implementation.

qa_pairs.question: What is the Extended UTXO Model (EUTXO) used in Ergo?
qa_pairs.answer: Ergo utilizes an enhanced version of Bitcoin's UTXO model, known as EUTXO, which enables Turing Complete smart contracts, parallel transaction processing, higher throughput compared to account-based models, and efficient state management.

qa_pairs.question: What are some recent protocol optimizations that have improved Ergo's efficiency?
qa_pairs.answer: Recent developments have improved the protocol's efficiency through the removal of unused complexity from the Sigma protocol, enhanced code readability and maintenance, refined transaction ordering and mempool tracking, and regular node version updates addressing performance.

qa_pairs.question: How does Ergo's Layer 1 design focus on scalability?
qa_pairs.answer: Ergo's Layer 1 is designed with a focus on scalability, incorporating features that boost transaction processing capacity and overall throughput.

qa_pairs.question: What are the core functions of Layer 1 in a blockchain system?
qa_pairs.answer: Layer 1, the foundational protocol layer of a blockchain system, is responsible for core functions such as transaction processing, consensus mechanisms, and security protocols.

sections.heading: Layer 1: On-chain Scalability in Ergo
sections.content: Layer 1, the foundational protocol layer of a blockchain system, is responsible for core functions such as transaction processing, consensus mechanisms, and security protocols. Ergo's Layer 1 is designed with a focus on scalability, incorporating features that boost transaction processing capacity and overall throughput.

sections.heading: Extended UTXO Model (EUTXO)
sections.content:
Ergo utilizes an enhanced version of Bitcoin's UTXO model, known as EUTXO, which enables:

- Turing Complete smart contracts
- Parallel transaction processing
- Higher throughput compared to account-based models
- Efficient state management

sections.heading: Protocol Optimizations
sections.content:
Recent developments have improved the protocol's efficiency through:

- Removal of unused complexity from the Sigma protocol
- Enhanced code readability and maintenance
- Refined transaction ordering and mempool tracking
- Regular node version updates addressing performance

sections.heading: Just-in-Time Costing
sections.content:
The introduction of [Just in time costing](jitc.md) in Node V5 has led to:

- 5-10x increase in block capacity
- Improved transaction processing capability
- More efficient resource utilization

sections.heading: Miner Parameter Adjustments
sections.content:
Developers are actively exploring:

- Increased block size parameters
- Enhanced transaction size limits
- Optimized mining efficiency
- Improved difficulty calculations through Autolykos updates

sections.heading: Microblocks and the Ergo Block Extension Section
sections.content:
Ergo's [block](block.md) structure includes extension sections containing:

- Mandatory and arbitrary key-value data
- Anchors for microblock creation
- Support for service chains
- Potential for generic sidechain implementation

These features enable:

- Faster block generation times
- Improved transaction throughput
- Support for velvet or soft forks
- Creation of Aspen-style service chains

sections.heading: Sub-Block Confirmation Protocols
sections.content:
Ergo is actively developing sub-block confirmation protocols that will:

- Group transactions into sub-blocks
- Reduce confirmation times
- Increase overall throughput
- Improve transaction processing efficiency

This development is guided by EIP-15 and builds upon established research from platforms like:

- [Bitcoin-NG](https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/nsdi16/nsdi16-paper-eyal.pdf)
- [Flux](https://www.usenix.org/system/files/atc20-li-chenxing.pdf)

sections.heading: Sharding
sections.content:
Sharding represents a promising avenue for future scalability improvements by:

- Partitioning the blockchain database into smaller segments
- Enabling parallel transaction processing
- Maintaining security while improving throughput

For detailed information, refer to:

- [On the Security and Performance of Blockchain Sharding](https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1276)
- [Sharding and Atomic Composability on Ergo](atomic-composability.md#sharding-and-its-impact-on-atomic-composability)

sections.heading: Ergo Improvement Proposals (EIPs)
sections.content:
EIPs serve as the primary mechanism for protocol enhancement through:

- Community-driven proposals
- Focused scalability improvements
- Systematic implementation processes
- Regular protocol updates

sections.heading: Node Version Updates
sections.content:
Regular updates to the Ergo node software provide:

- Bug fixes and performance enhancements
- New scalability features
- Improved difficulty calculations
- Refined Autolykos implementation

sections.heading: Research and Development
sections.content:
Ongoing research continues to explore:

- Advanced sharding techniques
- Novel consensus mechanisms
- Improved transaction ordering
- Enhanced mempool management

For the latest developments in these areas, refer to [Flux: Revisiting Near Blocks for Proof-of-Work Blockchains](https://eprint.iacr.org/2018/415.pdf).
